abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Credit Project
            will help re-establish internal, and external balances in
            Cape Verde, and alleviate the impact of the oil shock, by
            creating the conditions for sustained high GDP growth. The
            project will therefore support the Government's
            stabilization program, by implementing structural reforms in
            the petroleum sector, supporting an accelerated
            privatization program in the transport, and infrastructure
            sector, and by creating an environment, conducive to private
            sector development, thus enhancing revenue mobilization, in
            addition to fiscal strengthening, and balance of payments
            sustainability. While the main risk of the program is
            related to policy reversal, it is moderated by the fact that
            tax reform, and privatization are largely irreversible.
            Furthermore, the country's track record during most of
            the 1990s in terms of high growth, and poverty alleviation
            is good. Nevertheless, there were two instances where
            macroeconomic slippages occurred, leading to internal debt
            problems, though the Government responded with effective
            remedial measures. Hence, based on Government commitments,
            it is expected that the project will help ease the causes of
            overruns, such as petroleum subsidies, that the strong civil
            society support in government stabilization actions, and,
            the proposed reforms - which will enhance the business
            environment - will outweigh potential risks.
